description: As former President Donald J. Trump speeds toward the Republican nomination, President Biden is moving quickly to pump energy into his re-election bid, kicking off what is likely to be an ugly, dispiriting and historically long slog to November between two unpopular nominees.

title: The Audacity of E. Jean Carroll
description: Today she’s typically described as a former advice columnist, but that term doesn’t really do justice to E. Jean Carroll’s career pre-Donald Trump.

title: The Failed Promise of Police Body Cameras
description: Warning: This episode contains strong language and audio excerpts of violence.

title: Biden Vows to Retaliate, and a Super Bowl Rematch
description: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

title: Today’s Teenagers: Anxious About Their Futures and Disillusioned by Politicians
description: Although it has never been easy to be a teenager, the current generation of young Americans feels particularly apprehensive, new polling shows — anxious about their lives, disillusioned about the direction of the country and pessimistic about their futures.

title: Gaza’s Food Crisis
description: Mothers in Gaza are struggling to find clean water and baby formula for their newborns. Families are selling their possessions to buy sacks of flour. Some people are eating animal feed to survive.

title: Princess of Wales Returns Home From Hospital After Abdominal Surgery
description: Catherine, the Princess of Wales and the wife of Prince William, has returned home from a London hospital almost two weeks after undergoing abdominal surgery, Kensington Palace said in a statement on Monday.

title: The Results Are In: Here’s What Americans Streamed in 2023
description: Last year, studios continued to pull back how much they spend on new TV shows. A pair of strikes effectively shut down Hollywood for several months, disrupting new releases of television shows and movies.

title: Iran Denies Ordering Drone Strike as Biden Weighs a Response
description: The deaths of three U.S. soldiers in a drone strike in Jordan — the first-known American military fatalities from hostile fire in the widening Middle East crisis — are likely to increase pressure on President Biden, who has tried to limit the American response in order to keep regional tensions from spreading further.

title: China Evergrande Must Be Liquidated, a Judge Said. What Happens Next?
description: After nearly two years of false starts, last-ditch proposals and pleas for more time, China Evergrande, an enormous developer, has been ordered to dismantle itself. It’s a big moment. Evergrande’s collapse in 2021 sent China’s housing market into a tailspin. The worries in real estate, where most households put their savings, helped tip the economy into a downturn.

title: What Evergrande’s Collapse Might Mean for Global Business
description: A Hong Kong court on Monday ordered the liquidation of Evergrande, the heavily indebted Chinese property giant. The decision comes two years after the company defaulted, setting off a financial crisis at other developers and adding to the challenges facing the world’s second-largest economy.

title: Judge Denies Alex Murdaugh’s Request for a New Murder Trial
description: A judge declined on Monday to grant a new trial for Alex Murdaugh, the former South Carolina lawyer convicted of murdering his wife and son, who had argued that he was entitled to a redo because a court clerk had improperly influenced the jurors in his case.

title: Why the L.A. Public Library Acquired a Book Publisher
description: It’s Monday. Why the Los Angeles Public Library acquired a book publisher. Plus, more on why the editor in chief of The Los Angeles Times resigned this month.

title: How to Turn Your Catan Game Around
description: When your journalistic beat consists of providing helpful tips on how to win games, people naturally assume that you are an expert at playing them. That’s not always true, but I like to think that I make up for it with moxie and a reasonably consistent positive attitude.

title: Oregon Newspaper to Resume Printing After Embezzlement Forced Layoffs
description: A weekly newspaper in Oregon that laid off all of its workers in December after an employee embezzled tens of thousands of dollars will resume its print edition on Feb. 8 after raising enough money through donations, its editor said on Sunday.

title: Russian Figure Skater Is Handed Four-Year Ban in Olympic Doping Case
description: Kamila Valieva, the teenage Russian figure skater whose positive doping test upended her sport at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics and kept more than a dozen other athletes from receiving their medals, was banned from competition for four years on Monday by the top court in sports.

title: Walmart Offers Store Managers Company Stock to Make Them Feel Like ‘Owners’
description: Walmart, the nation’s largest private employer, is raising salaries and benefits for store managers as it looks for ways to retain them.

title: Trump Rages at U.A.W. President After Biden Endorsement
description: A few days after the United Auto Workers endorsed President Biden for re-election, former President Donald J. Trump raged at the union’s leader, Shawn Fain, on Sunday night.

title: Do You Know These Short Stories That Became Major Films?
description: Certain brief literary works have more than filled the big screen over the years. See how many stories and films you recognize in this quick quiz.

title: An Italian Holocaust Survivor Asks if She Has ‘Lived in Vain’
description: For decades, Liliana Segre visited Italian classrooms to recount her expulsion from school under Benito Mussolini’s anti-Semitic racial laws, her doomed attempt to flee Nazi-controlled Italy, her deportation from Milan’s train station to the death camps of Auschwitz. Her plain-spoken testimony about gas chambers, tattooed arms, casual atrocities and the murders of her father, grandparents and thousands of other Italian Jews made her the conscience and living memory of a country that often prefers not to remember.

title: Amazon Scraps Deal to Buy Maker of Roomba Amid Regulatory Scrutiny
description: Amazon said on Monday that it was abandoning plans to buy iRobot, the maker of the self-driving Roomba vacuum, after regulators raised concerns the deal would hurt competition.

title: King Charles Released From Hospital After Prostate Procedure
description: King Charles III was released from a London hospital on Monday after undergoing a procedure to treat an enlarged prostate, Buckingham Palace officials said.

title: Joni Mitchell Adds a Gig to Her Comeback Tour: The Grammys
description: Nine years ago, Joni Mitchell fans wondered if they might ever hear her perform again, after Mitchell — the Canadian singer-songwriter and icon of the folk movement — had an aneurysm that initially left her unable to speak.

title: U.K. to Ban Disposable Vapes in Plan to Combat Use by Children
description: The brightly colored packaging is a slick mix of ombré pink and lime green. The nicotine inside comes wreathed in a “strawberry kiwi” flavor.

title: Voting Is Bewildering This Primary Season. That Worries Experts.
description: Democracy is messy, but usually not this messy.

title: The Smile Gets Wonderfully Stranger
description: “Don’t think you know me,” Thom Yorke intones near the end of the Smile’s second studio album, “Wall of Eyes.” He adds, “Don’t think that I am everything you say.” With its new LP, the Smile makes itself increasingly elusive. It’s now a band intent on destabilizing structures and dissolving expectations.

title: Superpunchy One-Pan Eggplant Adobo
description: Substituting vegetables in traditionally meat-centric dishes is one of my favorite hacks — whether mushrooms for beef, zucchini for shrimp, or, as in Kay Chun’s new take on Filipino adobo, eggplant for chicken. It’s a brilliant swap: The eggplant stays just firm enough to hold its shape, but gets suffused with the tangy flavors of soy sauce, vinegar and garlic and the softness of coconut milk. Serve it over rice, with a handful of basil leaves or sliced scallions at the end to add a fresh and fragrant rush.

title: African National Congress Suspends Former President Jacob Zuma
description: South Africa’s governing party, the African National Congress, in a remarkable rebuke, suspended its former president, Jacob Zuma, on Monday, for launching “vitriolic attacks” against the organization after throwing his support behind a rival political party.

title: Philips Suspends U.S. Sales of Breathing Machines After Recall
description: Philips Respironics announced on Monday that it would halt sales of all of its breathing machines in the United States after reaching a settlement with the Food and Drug Administration over continuing problems with the devices.

title: French Farmers Lay ‘Siege’ to Paris in Growing Standoff
description: Irate farmers deployed tractors to block the main roads in and out of Paris on Monday, in an intensifying standoff that has left the capital girding for disruptions and has become the first major test for France’s newly appointed prime minister, Gabriel Attal.

title: Biden’s Options Range From Unsatisfying to Risky After American Deaths
description: Even before the drone strike that killed three U.S. service members in Jordan on Sunday, the Biden administration was planning for a moment just like this, debating how it might strike back in ways that would deter Iran’s proxy forces and send a message that Tehran would not miss.

title: Teen Drug and Alcohol Use Linked to Mental Health Distress
description: Teenagers who use cannabis, alcohol and nicotine are more likely to have underlying psychiatric symptoms, and worse symptoms, than their peers who are not regularly using substances, new research has found.

title: A ‘Substantial’ Atmospheric River Will Soak the West Coast This Week
description: Another atmospheric river will arrive in the northwestern United States on Tuesday, bringing excessive rain and mountain snow down the entire West Coast as it drifts south through Thursday.

title: Former N.H.L. Player Faces Sexual Assault Charges in Canada
description: A former National Hockey League player has been charged in Canada with sexual assault, his lawyer has confirmed, the latest development in a case that has brought turmoil to the sport’s Canadian governing body and angered many people across the country.

title: Audiobooks Are Booming. Spotify Wants in on the Action.
description: When Spotify announced last fall that it was adding audiobooks to its streaming service, reactions in the publishing world were mixed: Many publishers saw Spotify’s entrance as a chance to reach new audiences. But some agents and authors worried that streaming could erode the value of audiobooks, a lucrative and growing format.

title: 21 Savage Holds Off Green Day for a Second Week at No. 1
description: 21 Savage, the London-born Atlanta rapper, easily fended off a challenge from Green Day to hold at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a second week.

title: At Penn, Tensions May Only Be Growing After Magill’s Resignation
description: Campus protests are not usually aimed at a single person. But last week at the University of Pennsylvania, professors staged a rally targeting Marc Rowan, the New York private-equity billionaire.

title: He Stole Dorothy’s Ruby Slippers. He Thought They Had Real Rubies.
description: Nearly two decades after he broke into the Judy Garland Museum in Grand Rapids, Minn., and stole a pair of Dorothy’s ruby slippers used in “The Wizard of Oz,” the man who committed the theft has revealed why: He believed the slippers were adorned with real rubies.

title: The Messages of the E. Jean Carroll Verdict
description: To the Editor:

title: Mix-Up Preceded Deadly Drone Strike in Jordan, U.S. Officials Say
description: Air defenses failed to stop an attack on a U.S. military outpost in Jordan on Sunday that killed three American soldiers at least in part because the hostile drone approached its target at the same time an American drone was returning to the base, two U.S. officials said on Monday.

title: A Climate Change Success Story? Look at Hoboken
description: Note: This newsletter was sent to readers in November 2023. Headway is publishing the newsletter as an article to bring them together with other newsletters on site. Read them all here.

title: The Lessons of the Crime Wave That Didn’t Happen
description: Note: This newsletter was sent to readers in October 2023. Headway is publishing the newsletter as an article to bring them together with other newsletters on site. Read them all here.

title: Three Days That Changed the Thinking About Black Women’s Health
description: Note: This newsletter was sent to readers in December 2023. Headway is publishing the newsletter as an article to bring it together with other newsletters on site. Read them all here.

title: Hate Crimes Reported in Schools Nearly Doubled Between 2018 and 2022
description: The number of reported hate crimes in schools and colleges nearly doubled between 2018 and 2022, according to data released Monday by the F.B.I.

title: Defense Secretary Returns to Pentagon a Month After Surgery Complications
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III returned to the Pentagon on Monday for the first time in more than a month, the Defense Department said, after his surgery for prostate cancer and hospitalization for related medical complications.

title: Georgia Senators Press Biden for Tougher Tariffs on Chinese Solar Panels
description: A bipartisan quartet of senators, led by two Democrats from the critical swing state of Georgia, are asking President Biden to toughen up tariffs on Chinese solar panels or face a glutted market just as the president’s clean-energy tax credits hit the market.

title: French Farmers Block Roads Around Paris, Escalating Protests
description: Farmers around France sought to put pressure on the government over a wide range of grievances concerning the future of their industry.

title: How to Wash Your Hair
description: Don’t I know how to do this already? you might be asking. But while washing your hair might seem straightforward, a truly effective cleanse requires some thought and expertise. Just like the skin on our faces, each person’s scalp, and the hair that grows out of it, is different. Using the wrong products for your hair type can lead to oily roots, flaky skin and lackluster strands. What’s more, our hair’s needs can shift daily, so the best routine is one that’s both personalized and flexible. Here’s how to tailor your approach to achieve clean, healthy tresses.

title: U.N. to Study Reports of Sexual Violence in Israel During Oct. 7 Attack
description: A United Nations team has arrived in Israel to examine reports of sexual violence during the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7 even as Hamas and some critics of Israel continue to reject evidence that such assaults occurred.

title: N. Scott Momaday, Pulitzer-Winning Native American Novelist, Dies at 89
description: N. Scott Momaday, whose portrayal of a disaffected World War II veteran’s journey to spiritual renewal in his novel “House Made of Dawn” won a Pulitzer Prize, the first for a Native American author, heralding a more prominent place in contemporary literature for Native writers, died on Wednesday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 89.

title: Have Your Drinking Habits Changed in Recent Years?
description: Dry January is trickling to a close, marking the end of a month when many people rethink their relationship with drinking.

title: As Trump Awaits Fraud Penalty, a Monitor’s Report Could Raise His Risk
description: As a New York judge weighs Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud case, new accusations of deficiencies in his company’s financial reporting could provide the judge with ammunition for a forceful ruling against the former president and his family business.

title: After a Slow Start, Sundance Finishes With Plenty of Sales
description: Talk of the demise of the Sundance Film Festival as an incubator for audience-friendly independent films appears to have been greatly exaggerated.

title: The Promises and Problems of Buying Local
description: You can crisscross North Dakota from Fargo to Bismarck to Minot and never see a Walgreens, Rite-Aid or Walmart pharmacy. With narrow exceptions, a 1963 state law prohibits drugstores that aren’t majority-owned by a pharmacist. (CVS Health, whose predecessor company was already in the state in 1963, is grandfathered in.)

title: When the Governor Shotguns a Beer (or Maybe a Spiked Iced Tea)
description: It is an adage in politics that voters want to elect politicians they can see themselves sharing a beer with.

title: In Court, N.R.A. Questions Its Longtime Chief About His Luxury Spending
description: On Monday, Wayne LaPierre faced a second day of grilling on the witness stand about his lavish spending as the longtime chief of the National Rifle Association.

title: The Accusations Against the Atlanta Prosecutor Fani Willis: What We Know
description: The election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump and 14 of his allies in Georgia has been buffeted by allegations that the main prosecutor, Fani T. Willis, engaged in a romantic relationship with a lawyer she hired to help with the case.

title: Tuesday Briefing: U.S. Weighs a Response to the Drone Strike
description: President Biden must decide how far he is willing to go after a drone strike killed three U.S. soldiers at a base in Jordan on Sunday. He vowed to respond to the attack, which he blamed on militant groups backed by Iran, but retaliation could risk a wider war.

title: The World’s Biggest Jeweler Now Only Sources Recycled Metals
description: Pandora, known for its affordable sterling-silver charm bracelets, is the world’s largest jewelry company by volume: The Danish chain sells more than 100 million pieces annually. This week, it announced that it is now sourcing only 100-percent-recycled silver and gold for its collections.

title: Former Contractor Who Leaked Trump’s Tax Returns Sentenced to 5 Years in Prison
description: A former Internal Revenue Service contractor accused of leaking the tax documents of Donald J. Trump and other wealthy Americans was sentenced on Monday to five years in prison.

title: Skip the Flowers for a Sweethearts Cake From Nick Morgenstern
description: A dozen roses would be challenged to compete with the delectable Sweethearts Cake from Nick Morgenstern, the ice cream wizard. A raspberry-dusted slather of gossamer whipped cream covers a half-cylinder of Madagascar vanilla ice cream, set on raspberry sponge cake for a snowy, edible Quonset hut. Hearts of tart red fruit jam show up in each slice to punctuate the delicate sweetness. It serves four, but just two might make short work of it. Though this confection needs no embellishment, a few spoonfuls alongside raspberry coulis, a new intense sauce from Francine’s Outrageous Kitchen, puts it on a pedestal.

title: Vera Klement, Painter Who Saw Both Beauty and Evil, Dies at 93
description: In late 2009, as she was about to turn 80, Vera Klement was spattering and brushing red paint onto a 6-by-7-foot canvas on the floor of her loft in Chicago where she lived and worked. It depicted a faceless man, his arms pressed tightly to his chest, surrounded by a field of red. To the right, separated by white space, was a black rectangle.

title: Heavy Rain and Cold Worsen Conditions for Palestinians in Gaza
description: Days of torrential rains have exacerbated the dire humanitarian crisis in Gaza, where tens of thousands of people are displaced.

title: U.S. Charges Iranian Man and Two Canadians in Plot to Kill Refugees
description: An Iranian man accused of being the kingpin of a network that targets dissidents has been charged with hiring two Canadians, including a member of the Hells Angels, to kill two Iranian refugees living in Maryland, according to indictments unsealed on Monday.

title: They’ll Take the Travis Kelce — Hairdo, That Is
description: Jeffrey Dugas, who cuts hair at Obsidian Barbers in New Brunswick, Canada, has received a very specific request from clients in the past few weeks: They want the same style as Travis Kelce.

title: ‘The Greatest Night in Pop’ Review: They Were the World
description: In late 1984 the singer and activist Harry Belafonte was both impressed and perturbed by “Do They Know It’s Christmas?,” a British charity single featuring a cast of pop stars. The proceeds from the project went to Ethiopian famine relief. Belafonte complained to the music manager Ken Kragen, “We have white folks saving Black folks and we don’t have Black folks saving Black folks.”

title: U.N. Agency for Palestinians Imperiled by Terrorism Charges
description: Leaders of the largest United Nations agency in Gaza warned on Monday that it may soon run out of money as new allegations emerged about Hamas’s influence on the organization.

title: Court Clears Way for Italy to Send Some Asylum Seekers to Albania
description: An Albanian court on Monday gave the green light to an agreement allowing Italy to send migrants who are rescued in the Mediterranean by Italian ships to detention centers in Albania while their asylum claims are considered.

title: Party Like ‘Saltburn’ — Bathwater Optional
description: On Friday night at 3 Dollar Bill, a queer club in the East Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, partygoers danced and sang along to early 2000s hits by Fergie, Justin Timberlake and, of course, Sophie Ellis-Bextor whose “Murder on the Dancefloor” is currently having a renaissance.

title: A Drone Mix-Up Was Cited in the Deaths of 3 U.S. Troops
description: U.S. air defenses at a remote military outpost in Jordan failed to stop a deadly drone attack yesterday because it arrived at the same time that an American drone was returning to base, American officials said.

title: Defense Department Identifies 3 Soldiers Killed at Base in Jordan
description: The Department of Defense on Monday identified three Army Reserve soldiers who were killed at a U.S. base in Jordan on Sunday in what the Biden administration said was a drone attack from an Iran-backed militia. The department said at least 34 other service members were wounded in the attack.

title: Why Democrats Are Using Personal Abortion Stories
description: When Dr. Austin Dennard, an OB-GYN in Dallas, learned that her 11-week-old fetus had a fatal medical condition in July 2022, she immediately understood the medical implications.

title: Williamsburg. What Happened?
description: A four-decade timeline of total transformation in Brooklyn.

title: MAGA Is Based on Fear, Not Grounded in Reality
description: A few days ago, Kristi Noem, the Republican governor of South Dakota — a MAGA hard-liner sometimes mentioned as a potential running mate for Donald Trump — warned that President Biden is “remaking” America, turning us into Europe. My first thought was: So he’s going to raise our life expectancy by five or six years? In context, however, it was clear that Noem believes, or expects her audience to believe, that Europe is a scene of havoc wrought by hordes of immigrants.

title: Officials Propose to Hamas a Six-Week War Pause and a Hostage-Prisoner Swap
description: Representatives from four nations have agreed to have Qatar present a nascent framework to Hamas that proposes a six-week pause in the war in Gaza for Hamas to exchange some hostages for Palestinian prisoners held by Israel, officials say.

title: Norfolk Southern Agrees to Try Out Federal Safety Reporting Program
description: Norfolk Southern, the operator of the freight train carrying toxic chemicals that derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, nearly a year ago, has agreed to participate in a federal program that allows employees to report safety issues confidentially, the company and federal officials announced on Monday.

title: Colombia, a Usually Wet Nation, Reels Amid Widespread Wildfires
description: Helicopters hauling buckets of water fly toward the mountains where fires burn, a thick haze periodically covers the sky, and residents have been ordered to wear masks and limit driving because of the poor air quality.

title: Jimy Williams, A.L. Manager of the Year in Boston in ’99, Dies at 80
description: Jimy Williams, the 1999 American League Manager of the Year for Boston who won 910 games over a dozen seasons that included stints with Toronto and Houston, died on Friday in Tarpon Springs, Fla. He was 80.

title: Canada Delays Plan to Offer Medically Assisted Death to the Mentally Ill
description: Canada is postponing a plan to offer people suffering from mental illnesses the option of a medically assisted death, two cabinet ministers said on Monday.

title: Northern Ireland’s D.U.P. Signals End to Political Deadlock After 2 Years
description: The Democratic Unionist Party, the main Protestant party in Northern Ireland and one of its biggest political forces, said on Tuesday that it was ready to return to power sharing after a boycott of almost two years had paralyzed decision-making in the region.

title: Arkansas Authorities Capture Second Escaped Inmate
description: The authorities in Arkansas on Monday captured a capital murder suspect who had escaped from a local jail with another inmate, ending a weeklong manhunt.

title: Washed Out
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: 5 Men Arrested in Mojave Desert Killings That Remained a Mystery for Days
description: The authorities in Southern California announced on Monday that they had arrested five men in connection with the six people found fatally shot at a remote crossroads in the Mojave Desert last week, a grisly scene that investigators believe stemmed from a dispute over marijuana.

title: Man Who Shot Bride and Bishop at Wedding Gets 50 Years to Life in Prison
description: A gunman who opened fire in a New Hampshire church during a wedding, wounding the bride and bishop, was sentenced Monday to a minimum of 50 years to life in prison.

title: Neuralink Implanted a Device in a Patient’s Brain, Elon Musk Says
description: Neuralink, a company working to develop computer interfaces that can be implanted in human brains, placed its first device in a patient on Sunday, said its founder, Elon Musk.

title: Quote of the Day: More Than Ever, Teenagers See a Bleak Future
description: “The data is pretty stark: Our kids are not all right.”

title: China’s Real Estate Crisis ‘Has Not Touched Bottom’
description: The unwavering belief of Chinese home buyers that real estate was a can’t-lose investment propelled the country’s property sector to become the backbone of its economy.

title: Tuesday Briefing
description: President Biden is faced with a decision on how far he is willing to go after a drone strike killed three U.S. soldiers at a base in Jordan on Sunday. He vowed to respond to the attack, which he blamed on militant groups backed by Iran, but retaliation could risk a wider war.

title: If It Isn’t Perfect, Is It Still K-Pop?
description: What comes to mind when you hear the word “K-pop”? Is it the global boy band phenomenon BTS, wearing studded jackets and dancing in perfect sync? Or the girl group Blackpink, performing at Coachella in trendy fashions and perfectly curled hair?

title: Word of the Day: oneiric
description: The word oneiric has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 2 in the book review “Daniel Clowes Dreams of the Apocalypse” by Junot Díaz:

title: Aid Group Calls Halts in Funding for UNRWA ‘Reckless’
description: Aid groups working in Gaza expressed dismay at the decision by some donor nations to suspend funding to the main U.N. agency operating in the territory, calling the move “reckless” at a moment when the humanitarian crisis there is rapidly getting worse.

title: Stephen Colbert Is Hoping for a Taylor Swift Super Bowl
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: New Subway Fare Gates and Platform Barriers Fail to Impress New Yorkers
description: Transit officials have struggled for years with two of the subway system’s most vexing problems: the dozens of people struck by trains every year and the millions of dollars lost to fare beaters. In the latest efforts to find solutions, they are testing new fare gates to stop turnstile jumpers and metal platform barriers to keep riders safe.

title: Mayor Adams Loses Showdown Over 2 Criminal Justice Bills
description: Police officers will be required to record the race, age and gender of most people they stop and solitary confinement will be banned in New York City jails after the City Council overrode Mayor Eric Adams’s veto of two criminal justice bills on Tuesday.

title: In Peru, a Mission to Save the Stingless Bee
description: As a child, Heriberto Vela, an Indigenous resident of Loreto, Peru, watched his father pull nests of wild stingless bees from trees in the Amazon forest. Together, the two then extracted honey from the nests to help cure colds and other ailments.

title: Taylor Swift and the N.F.L.
description: Please note: We ask that adults respect the intent of our writing prompts and refrain from posting here. While there are many other places on nytimes.com for adults to have their say, this is the only part of the site that explicitly invites the voices of young people.

title: Imran Khan Sentenced to 10 Years Ahead of Pakistan’s Elections
description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan was sentenced to 10 years in prison on Tuesday, the latest twist in what is widely seen as a campaign by the military to sideline one of its leading critics.

title: Letter to San Zaw Htway
description: After the 2021 military coup in Myanmar, loved ones of the deceased artist and political prisoner San Zaw Htway wrote him letters as an act of remembrance and hope.

title: Our Friend Is Gone, but He Lives Through Our Resistance in Myanmar
description: San Zaw Htway was an artist, activist, political prisoner and dear friend.

title: A Return to the Fatherland in Search of a Missing Father
description: “Hard by a Great Forest,” by Leo Vardiashvili, is a novel-as-postcard from a dissolute Georgia. Our narrator, the self-abnegating and guilt-ridden Saba, fled the former Soviet republic with his father and brother amid civil war, and arrived in 1990s London at the age of 8. Nearly two decades later, his father, Irakli, flies alone to Tbilisi to reconcile his past and goes missing. “I left a trail I can’t erase,” reads Irakli’s final message to his sons. “Do not follow it.” Naturally, Saba follows.

title: An America Where Guns Do the Talking
description: Last year, a friend from Brunei visited me in the United States. She is American but was raised in Sudan and has lived in Cambodia and Scotland, among other places. We were talking about the rise in anxiety among teenagers in America when another friend texted me; her daughter had just arrived home from school, where she’d spent the afternoon in lockdown. “Of course your kids have anxiety,” my Brunei friend said. “They’re being raised in a war zone.”

title: The Curmudgeon of Rivington Street
description: The drag queens who once paraded through the hallways are long gone.

title: Joel Embiid Wants the African Diaspora to Flourish Onscreen
description: Joel Embiid knew as early as his rookie season in the National Basketball Association that he eventually wanted to enter the media industry.

title: The Most Powerful Person in Publishing Doesn’t Like to Talk About Himself
description: As chief executive of Penguin Random House, Nihar Malaviya runs a global company and the largest book publisher in the United States — a powerful cultural force that helps drive public debate and shape the country’s entertainment and literary worlds.

title: Is Lip Balm Making My Chapped Lips Worse?
description: Q: My lips are always dry, and I’m applying lip balm on repeat. Could this be exacerbating the problem?

title: 394 Hot Dog Ice Sculptures Later, He Quit His Day Job
description: One day this summer, a man in Seattle gathered ingredients to make hot dogs: sausages, buns, a 50-pound block of aluminum.

title: The Women of ‘Feud: Capote vs. the Swans’ Are Birds of a Feather
description: The first season of Ryan Murphy’s “Feud” aired in 2017. A juicy survey of the bitter rivalry between Bette Davis and Joan Crawford, the co-stars of “What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?,” the show earned 18 Emmy nominations, winning two. A second season, based on Prince Charles and Princess Diana’s troubled marriage, was developed then scrapped, mostly because Murphy felt that he could never outdo “The Crown.” Another iteration, centered on William F. Buckley and Gore Vidal, also fell apart. Murphy and his producers toyed with a half dozen other ideas, though never for very long.

title: Is True Crime As a Form of Entertainment Ethical?
description: True crime entertainment seems to be everywhere these days. Are you a fan? Do you listen to podcasts, read books, or watch documentaries, TV shows and movies that tell the stories of real-life victims and perpetrators?

title: Do Housing Developers Need a (Tax) Break?
description: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about a tax break that expired in 2022 — and why the fight over replacing it has implications for New York City’s future. We’ll also get details on why the City Council is expected to override Mayor Eric Adams’s veto of two bills today.

title: Watch Me Lose My Job on TikTok
description: “I am about to get laid off,” Folashade Ade-Banjo spoke to the camera while positioning her phone, “and you are about to see it.”

title: What Your Laundry Says About Your Life
description: My father has placed me in the basket and layered laundry neatly on top of me, then topped everything with a crocheted blanket. Time stamp: epitome of the ’70s. I’m ... 5? He has employed a classic parental trick, his version called Rock, inspired by Frank Zappa’s “Help, I’m a Rock,” which I also recommend. The game was: Pretend you’re a rock. You’re quiet. You’re still. I remember the weight of the laundry, the solemnity of my task and the laughter just beneath it. Something about the princess and the pea: being the pea.

title: Linda Ronstadt’s Tucson
description: In the course of becoming a Rock & Roll Hall of Famer, a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award winner and the subject of a forthcoming biopic set to star Selena Gomez, Linda Ronstadt has packed theaters around the globe. But her favorite sits on a one-way side street in Tucson, Ariz.

title: What Can Americans Agree on? Wolves.
description: For generations, America waged a war against the wolf; now with the animals repopulating the Mountain West, the wolf war has taken on a new shape: pitting neighbors against neighbors as they fight over how to manage wolves.

title: Trump Has Devoured the Republican Establishment
description: It was almost 15 months ago that The New York Post published a full-page cover photo of Ron DeSantis with the headline “DeFUTURE.” His 19-point victory in the Florida governor’s race was one of the few bright spots of the 2022 elections for a weary Republican elite, which was desperately looking to move on from Donald Trump after his handpicked candidates cost the party key Senate seats.

title: Why Cut Rates in an Economy This Strong? A Big Question Confronts the Fed.
description: The Federal Reserve is widely expected to leave interest rates unchanged at the conclusion of its meeting on Wednesday, but investors will be watching closely for any hint at when and how much it might lower those rates this year.

title: How Do You Make a Weed Empire? Sell It Like Streetwear.
description: The closest thing to a bat signal for stoners is the blue lettering of the Cookies logo. When a new storefront comes to a strip mall or a downtown shopping district, fans flock to grand-opening parties, drawn by a love of the brand — one based on more than its reputation for selling extremely potent weed. Until recently, the company was largely a West Coast phenomenon, but as marijuana legalization spread east, so did Cookies. A little over a year after recreational sales became legal in New Jersey, the chain opened a new location in a bland outdoor mall in Harrison, its aesthetic landing somewhere in the startup-meets-streetwear zone between Apple and Kith. I walked over to a large circular table laden with dozens of jars, each containing a different strain. There were longtime Cookies stalwarts like Gary Payton, a collaboration with the N.B.A. legend, and new variants with names like Mexican Flan and Dirty Muffler.

title: Truck Makers Team Up to Push for Electric Vehicle Chargers
description: There are more than four million electric vehicles on American roads, but fewer than 1,000 of them are heavy-duty trucks. On Tuesday, the three largest truck makers announced a push to remedy that deficit by calling on governments and utilities to help them build many more places to charge big rigs.

title: Focused Cuts and Fewer Layers: Tech Layoffs Enter a New Phase
description: Last year, Mark Zuckerberg declared 2023 to be a “year of efficiency.” His company, Meta, soon laid off a third of its employees. Amazon, Google and Microsoft also cut tens of thousands of workers.

title: What Biden Can Do After Another Failed Border Deal
description: A bipartisan immigration deal to restrict border crossings took a hit last week when Donald Trump pushed Congress to reject it. It’s the latest in a series of episodes over the last decade where one party blows up a deal just as the other gives in. President Biden wants to break this cycle, but to get the politics right, he must get the policy right first.

title: U.S. Will Pay to Add Solar Panels to Hospitals, Schools After Disasters
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency will begin paying to install solar panels on schools, hospitals and other public buildings that are rebuilt after disasters, making them more resilient against future disasters while reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

title: I’m Not a Fan of TikTok, but We Can’t Blame It for Everything
description: Gen Z and younger millennials are taking to apps like TikTok to express their anger about everything from the conflict in the Middle East to the cost of living. Some politicians are not happy. In this audio essay, the Opinion columnist Zeynep Tufekci argues that lawmakers should stop blaming social media platforms for corrupting people’s minds and instead concentrate on oversight and demand transparency from them.

title: Biden Super PAC Plans a Historic $250 Million Ad Blitz
description: The main Democratic super PAC supporting President Biden’s re-election bid, Future Forward, is beginning this week to reserve $250 million in advertising across the most important battleground states, a blitz that it says is the largest single purchase of political advertising by a super PAC in the nation’s history.

title: First Bird Flu Deaths Reported in Antarctic Penguins
description: A highly lethal form of bird flu has been detected in Antarctic penguins for the first time. The virus, which is known as H5N1, was confirmed in two gentoo penguins that were found dead on Sea Lion Island in the Falkland Islands, a British territory.

title: House Panel Approves Impeachment Charges Against Mayorkas
description: The House Homeland Security Committee approved two articles of impeachment early Wednesday against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, over his handling of the southwestern border, as Republicans raced forward with a partisan indictment of President Biden’s immigration policies.

title: More Money for Parents? Both Parties Just Might Make It Happen.
description: At a time when congressional Democrats and Republicans seem unable to agree on almost anything, they may soon pass an expanded child tax credit, which gives money to parents.

title: 6 Great Space Images in January
description: A rocket launching from the ocean, an asteroid hits Earth's atmosphere and more out of this world visual highlights from the past month.

title: If It Walks Like an Insurrection and Talks Like an Insurrection …
description: While we await oral argument in Trump v. Anderson — the U.S. Supreme Court case that will evaluate the Colorado Supreme Court’s decision to exclude the former president from the state’s Republican primary ballot — it’s worth revisiting the arguments leveled against the Colorado court’s decision and, by extension, its interpretation of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.

title: The War the World Can’t See
description: To many people outside Gaza, the war flashes by as a doomscroll of headlines and casualty tolls and photos of screaming children, the bloody shreds of somebody else’s anguish.

title: She Gave Birth Two Weeks Ago. Now She’s in a Beauty Pageant.
description: “I am still bleeding a little,” Hannah Neeleman said.

title: Eurozone Economy Flatlines, Raising Concerns About Falling Behind
description: The eurozone economy stagnated late last year as a lingering energy crisis sparked a loss of competitiveness in some European industries, and consumers reined in spending to grapple with high living costs, Europe’s statistics agency reported Tuesday.

title: Trump’s Voters vs. Haley’s Donors
description: Inside the Republican Party, a class war is playing out between the pro-Trump base, which is ready for the nomination fight to be over, and the anti-Trump donor class, which thinks it’s just getting started.

title: U.S. Weighs Retaliation After Strike in Jordan, and Farmers Lay ‘Siege’ to Paris
description: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

title: Russian Skaters Stripped of Olympic Gold, Setting Up New Fight for Medals
description: International skating’s governing body on Tuesday sought to put an end to a two-year-old controversy by revising the disputed results of a marquee figure skating competition at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics. But in stripping Russia of its victory in the team event, awarding the gold medal to the United States and denying Canada the bronze it had been expecting, the sport may have only set the stage for yet another protracted legal fight.

title: Amazon Filmed ‘Expats’ in Hong Kong, but People There Can’t Watch It
description: At the height of Hong Kong’s Covid restrictions, the government gave Nicole Kidman and several others a rare exemption from the weeks of hotel quarantine required for travelers so that they could film a series about the malaise of privileged expatriates.

title: G.M. Profits Hurt by Electric Car Business and Strike
description: General Motors said on Tuesday that its profit in the final three months of 2023 was depressed by the cost of a 40-day strike at some of its U.S. plants and an accounting charge related to electric vehicles.

title: Experimental Drug Cuts Off Pain at the Source, Company Says
description: Vertex Pharmaceuticals of Boston announced Tuesday that it had developed an experimental drug that relieves moderate to severe pain, blocking pain signals before they can get to the brain. It works only on peripheral nerves — those outside the brain and the spinal cord — making it unlike opioids. Vertex says its new drug is expected to avoid opioids’ potential to lead to addiction.

title: Hong Kong Pushes New Security Law to Root Out ‘Seeds of Unrest’
description: The Hong Kong government will enact a long-shelved security law to curb foreign influence and expand the definition of offenses like stealing state secrets and treason, officials announced on Tuesday, in a move expected to further silence dissent in the once-freewheeling Chinese territory.

title: What Iran Really Wants
description: Iran has emerged as the chief architect in multiple conflicts strafing the Middle East, from the Mediterranean to the Persian Gulf.

title: Israeli Forces Kill a Hamas Commander Inside a West Bank Hospital, Military Says
description: Israeli forces stormed a Palestinian hospital in the occupied West Bank early Tuesday morning, killing three militants, including a commander in Hamas, according to the Israeli military and Palestinian officials.

title: Megan Thee Stallion and Nicki Minaj: Who’s Mad at Whom?
description: In terms of social media oxygen consumed, not even Taylor Swift’s making it into the Super Bowl could compete with the weekend’s real main event: the very public drawing of battle lines between two titans of contemporary hip-hop.

title: North Atlantic Right Whale Found Dead Near Martha’s Vineyard
description: A female North Atlantic right whale was found dead on Sunday with a rope wrapped around it off the coast of Martha’s Vineyard, Mass., a rare event that had scientists worrying about the future of the critically endangered species with about 360 remaining animals.

title: Global Economy Is Heading Toward ‘Soft Landing,’ I.M.F. Says
description: The global economy has been battered by a pandemic, record levels of inflation, protracted wars and skyrocketing interest rates over the past four years, raising fears of a painful worldwide downturn. But fresh forecasts published on Tuesday suggest that the world has managed to defy the odds, averting the threat of a so-called hard landing.

title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Oscar Nominations, Football, Primaries
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

title: Tax Break Scandal Leads to $5 Million Fine for N.J. Energy Company
description: A business tied to George Norcross III, a high-profile New Jersey Democrat, has agreed to pay a $5 million penalty after a criminal investigation into hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks that the energy company, Holtec International, was awarded.

title: Technology Companies Are Cutting Jobs and Wall Street Likes It
description: Tech giants are set to report quarterly earnings, starting on Tuesday with Alphabet and Microsoft. Wall Street is expecting good news, including more progress on artificial intelligence.

title: Saudi Aramco Abruptly Drops Plans to Expand Oil Production
description: Saudi Aramco said Tuesday that it would call off plans to expand its oil output, a remarkable turnaround by one of the world’s leading petroleum producers.

title: Ukraine’s Latest Challenge: Festering Tension Among Top Leaders
description: As Ukraine fights against a fierce Russian offensive and its leaders wait to see whether their Western allies will approve more than $100 billion in much-needed assistance, the government in Kyiv is dealing with a festering distraction: tumult in its top ranks centered on the fate of the top military commander.

title: French Government Vows Rapid Aid for Farmers but Blockades Persist
description: Prime Minister Gabriel Attal promised more aid for French agriculture on Tuesday and vowed to shield it from “unfair competition” in an attempt to appease protesting farmers, but many appeared unmoved by his efforts as they blocked major roads around Paris for a second day.

title: Minute-Long Soap Operas Are Here. Is America Ready?
description: When Albee Zhang received an offer to produce cheesy short-form features made for phones last spring, she was skeptical, and so, she declined.

title: Love Letters to California
description: On a recent short drive from my home in San Francisco, I ended up in Petaluma, where I had as close to a perfect day as possible.

title: New York Asks Realty Company to Investigate Sexual Assault Allegations
description: The New York state comptroller has asked the real estate brokerage eXp Realty to open an independent investigation into sexual harassment and assault allegations exposed in a New York Times article last month.

title: Arms Dealer Linked to Myanmar Junta Acquitted in Thai Money Laundering Case
description: A wealthy Myanmar arms broker with close ties to the leader of Myanmar’s brutal military regime was acquitted on Tuesday by a Bangkok court on charges of drug trafficking and money laundering, raising fears that he will be free to resume his activities aiding the junta.

title: Taylor Swift, Travis Kelce and a MAGA Meltdown
description: For football fans eager to see a new team in the Super Bowl, the conference championship games on Sunday that sent the Kansas City Chiefs and San Francisco 49ers back to the main event of American sports culture were sorely disappointing.

title: ‘Passport’ Review: A Master of Comedy in a Migrant Camp
description: Badly injured from a fight, a man wakes up in the Calais Jungle, a ramshackle camp for migrants in northern France. His memory is gone, and all he has on him is an Eritrean passport with the name “Issa.”

title: A Monkey Is on the Run in the Scottish Highlands
description: Was it a longing for freedom, for friends or for snacks that pushed the monkey to make his daring getaway?

title: Britain’s Foreign Secretary Signals Willingness to Recognize Palestinian State Sooner
description: David Cameron, Britain’s foreign secretary, has signaled that Britain is willing to move up conversations about formally recognizing a Palestinian state, saying that his country and other allies should show Palestinians “irreversible progress” toward that long-sought goal.

title: Apocalyptic Scenes as Workers Sift Through Rubble in Turkey
description: This was featured on the home screen.

title: Monkey Eats From Bird Feeder After Escaping Scottish Wildlife Park
description: A Japanese macaque was spotted in a man’s backyard after it escaped from Highland Wildlife Park in Scotland.

title: Attacking, and Defending, D.E.I. in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Syphilis Is Soaring in the U.S.
description: Syphilis, once nearly eliminated in the United States, continues to resurge, reaching the highest rate of new infections recorded since 1950, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Tuesday.

title: Breakfast for Dinner!
description: Egg lovers, rejoice: This week we’re talking breakfast for dinner, a beloved genre of cooking and a subject that several of you requested when I asked if you were interested last week. (Sample reader email in my inbox: “Brunch, brinner!! All breakfast edition YES!”)

title: Haley Says U.S. Should ‘Go After’ Iranian Military Over Deadly Drone Strike
description: Nikki Haley suggested on Tuesday morning that the United States should “go after” Iranian military leaders in response to the drone attack by an Iran-backed militia that killed three American service members.

title: At 80, the Modest Queen of Contemporary Music Keeps Exploring
description: On a cold afternoon in early January, the pianist Ursula Oppens was making an album at Brooklyn College.

title: Jury Finds Sotheby’s Did Not Help in Any Fraud of Russian Oligarch
description: A jury in a civil trial in New York decided in favor of Sotheby’s on Tuesday, rejecting a Russian oligarch’s claim that the auction house had helped a Swiss dealer who he said defrauded him out of tens of millions of dollars in high-end art sales.

title: How Does Alcohol Affect the Gut Microbiome?
description: A frothy beer or a glass of wine can enhance a meal and settle the mind. But what does alcohol do to the trillions of microbes living in your gut?

title: Jaap van Zweden, New York Phil Maestro, Takes Podium in Seoul
description: In New York, Jaap van Zweden, the New York Philharmonic’s music director, is preparing to say goodbye: Farewell concerts under the banner “Celebrate Jaap!” are planned over the next few months before his brief, pandemic-interrupted tenure ends this summer.

title: Hope Wanes Amid the Wreckage Where 600 Apartments Once Stood
description: This was featured on the home screen.

title: UPS to Cut 12,000 Jobs as Wages Rise and Package Volumes Fall
description: United Parcel Service plans to cut about 12,000 jobs this year as the company tries to slash costs in the face of falling package volumes and higher wages linked to a union contract it signed in the summer.

title: How the Border Crisis Shattered Biden’s Immigration Hopes
description: On President Biden’s first day in office, he paused nearly all deportations. He vowed to end the harsh practices of the Trump administration, show compassion toward those wishing to come to the United States and secure the southern border.

title: Video Shows Gunmen Storming West Bank Hospital
description: The Palestinian Authority Health Ministry released surveillance video that shows several armed Israeli forces dressed in civilian clothes inside Ibn Sina Specialized Hospital in Jenin.

title: Khaled Nezzar, General at Center of Algeria’s Bloodshed, Dies at 86
description: Khaled Nezzar, a wily, outspoken Algerian general and former defense minister who played a central role in the bloodshed that marked his troubled country’s passage out of the 20th century, died on Dec. 29 in Algiers. He was 86.

title: Is It Safe to Travel to the Bahamas? Here’s What You Need to Know.
description: Drawn by clear turquoise waters and miles of white-sand beaches, around seven million travelers visit the Bahamas each year, but a new warning about increased violence on the island nation has raised alarm over the safety of visiting there.

title: Video Shows Gunmen Storming West Bank Hospital
description: The Palestinian Authority Health Ministry released surveillance video that shows armed members of Israeli forces dressed in civilian clothes inside Ibn Sina Specialized Hospital in Jenin.

title: Study Tracking Women’s Music Credits Has a Surprise: Good News
description: Each year since 2018, the University of Southern California’s Annenberg Inclusion Initiative has tracked the number of women credited on the music industry’s biggest hits, and the numbers have usually been dismal — year after year, female artists, songwriters and producers have been crowded out by men, sometimes by extraordinary margins.

title: Lizards, Monkeys and Bears, Oh My! Try the Animal Movement Workout.
description: Lately, my workouts have looked a bit odd: I’ve been slithering like a lizard, crawling like a bear and scuttling like a crab. It’s called quadrupedal movement training (or animal movement), and it’s taken over TikTok (the related hashtag, #primalmovement, has 2.4 billion views).

title: Boeing Faces Tricky Balance Between Safety and Financial Performance
description: Less than four weeks after a hole blew open on a Boeing 737 Max 9 jet during a flight, company executives face a thorny question: Should they emphasize safety or financial performance?

title: Trump Stays on Ballot in Illinois, State Board Rules
description: The Illinois State Board of Elections rejected a complaint on Tuesday that accused former President Donald J. Trump of insurrection by trying to remain in office after losing the 2020 election, and that sought to disqualify him from the state’s primary ballot.

title: Josephine Baker, Still Moving
description: There was no shortage of epithets for Josephine Baker, the St. Louis-born polymath who took Paris by storm when she arrived there in 1925, aged 19, to headline “La Revue Nègre,” a show of all-Black performers at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées.

title: Citi Is Sued by New York State Over Account Transfer Fraud
description: New York State’s attorney general sued Citi on Tuesday, accusing it of failing to stop scammers from stealing an unspecified amount of money from customer accounts, and saying the bank should reimburse fraud victims for any losses.

title: Justice Department Investigating Cori Bush’s Handling of Campaign Funds
description: The Justice Department is conducting an investigation into whether Representative Cori Bush mishandled campaign funds, including when she hired her romantic partner — who is now her husband — to provide her with security services.

title: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
description: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.

title: War in Ukraine Has Weakened Putin, C.I.A. Director Writes
description: The war in Ukraine has “quietly corroded” the power of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, the C.I.A. director, William J. Burns, wrote in an essay published on Tuesday.

title: The Secret of Thomas Mann’s Translator
description: Before she could sign on to translate the entirety of Thomas Mann, the giant of German letters, into English, Helen Tracy Lowe-Porter had to translate herself.

title: Patagonia’s Profits Are Funding Conservation — and Politics
description: A little more than $3 million to block a proposed mine in Alaska. Another $3 million to conserve land in Chile and Argentina. And $1 million to help elect Democrats around the country, including $200,000 to a super PAC this month.

title: A Lead Scare Strikes Stanley Tumblers, but You Don’t Need to Worry
description: You might have heard of the Stanley tumbler, the hip, trendy water bottle that has people camping outside stores or getting into fights to get their hands on one.

title: Trump Is Turning Court Appearances Into Campaign Stops
description: The New York Times’ Jonathan Swan analyzes Donald J. Trump’s campaign strategy in the court room.

title: ‘A Long Time Coming’: Northern Ireland Deal Receives Broad Welcome
description: Britain, Ireland and the United States on Tuesday welcomed a deal to end almost two years of political deadlock in Northern Ireland that will, for the first time, hand the territory’s top leadership role to Sinn Fein, a party that mainly represents Roman Catholic voters committed to a united Ireland.

title: Zuma’s Enduring Appeal Threatens His Old Allies’ Hold on South Africa
description: When the African National Congress suspended former President Jacob Zuma this week, a top party official portrayed him as a traitor to the ongoing struggle for Black prosperity in South Africa and a symbol of corruption that the organization is looking to move past.

title: Was 1968 the Grammys’ Best Year Ever?
description: The 66th annual Grammy Awards take place on Sunday, and this year’s lineup of performers is pretty exceptional. I mean, Joni Mitchell is performing! For the first time ever at the Grammys! I could really just stop there, but Billy Joel, Billie Eilish, SZA, U2, Olivia Rodrigo, Burna Boy, Luke Combs, Dua Lipa, Travis Scott and more are scheduled to grace the stage. Will Joel and Eilish take this opportunity to start a supergroup called the Billies? Will SZA and U2 start an all-caps collaborative side project called SUZA2? Will Travis Scott meet Joni Mitchell, and if so, what will they talk about? The possibilities of this year’s ceremony are endless, and a little weird.

title: A Mind-Bending 7-Hour Epic About Hitler Gets a Rare Screening
description: This weekend, the hottest ticket in New York is a seven-hour-plus movie about Adolf Hitler.

title: Here’s How the Next Two Atmospheric Rivers Will Affect California
description: Forecasters have warned California residents that unsettled weather through Thursday is likely to bring heavy rains, strong winds and mountain snow as another atmospheric river moves down along the West Coast. Another storm will threaten the region early next week.

title: Trump’s PACs Spent Roughly $50 Million on Legal Expenses in 2023
description: Donald J. Trump piled up legal expenses in 2023 as he was indicted four times, spending approximately $50 million in donor money on legal bills and investigation-related expenses last year, according to two people briefed on the figure.

title: Virginia Moves to End Legacy Admissions at Its Public Universities
description: Virginia is on track to ban legacy preferences at its public universities, which give a boost to children of alumni who apply for admission.

title: Israeli Military Confirms It Has Begun Flooding Hamas Tunnels
description: The Israeli military said Tuesday that it had begun pumping water into the vast network of tunnels beneath Gaza, which Hamas has used to launch attacks, store weapons and imprison Israeli hostages.

title: Law Enforcement Braces for Flood of Child Sex Abuse Images Generated by A.I.
description: Law enforcement officials are bracing for an explosion of material generated by artificial intelligence that realistically depicts children being sexually exploited, deepening the challenge of identifying victims and combating such abuse.

title: Chita Rivera, Electrifying Star of Broadway and Beyond, Is Dead at 91
description: Chita Rivera, the fire-and-ice dancer, singer and actress who leapt to stardom in the original Broadway production of “West Side Story” and dazzled audiences for nearly seven decades as a Puerto Rican lodestar of the American musical theater, died on Tuesday in New York. She was 91.

title: Abolish the U.N.’s Palestinian Refugee Agency
description: United Nations agencies and officials are no strangers to scandal and infamy.

title: German Authorities Seize $2 Billion Worth of Bitcoin
description: A German programmer who is accused of running an illegal movie streaming site more than a decade ago transferred $2.17 billion worth of Bitcoin to the authorities to repay at least some of the money he had made illegally, the police said on Tuesday. The transfer required the man to use his unique Bitcoin credentials to hand over the funds.

title: Colleges Won’t Get FAFSA Data Until March, Delaying Aid Offers
description: It may be another few months before millions of students and families know how much they’ll have to pay for college this fall.

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘He’s a Minimalist; I’m a Hoarder’
description: For our 12th anniversary, I gave my boyfriend an empty box, his most-wanted anti-gift. He’s a minimalist; I’m a hoarder. That difference has been the source of our most epic and ongoing arguments. Whenever I ask what I should buy him, he tells me to clear out my belongings from his closet. This January, I finally did. Rather than painstakingly analyzing each photo, tangled piece of jewelry or DVD in my box marked “mementos,” I set a timer for 30 minutes and discarded ruthlessly. It was difficult, but his grin was worth it. — Rachel Kramer Bussel

title: Using A.I., Hollywood Agency and Tech Start-Up Aim to Protect Artists
description: The talent agency WME announced a partnership with the technology firm Vermillio on Tuesday that it hopes will protect its clients from having their likenesses misused through artificial intelligence technology.

title: What’s the Matter With Europe?
description: In my most recent column I had a bit of fun with Kristi Noem, the governor of South Dakota, who has ominously warned that President Biden will turn us into Europe. I joked that this would mean adding five or six years to our life expectancy. When I shared Noem’s remarks on social media, some of my correspondents asked whether this meant that we’re about to get good train service and better food.

title: Chita Rivera, Finding Her Voice
description: Yes, the legs. Yes, the line. Yes, the look.

title: An Explorer Believes He Found Amelia Earhart’s Plane. Experts Aren’t Convinced.
description: It is one of the greatest enduring mysteries in aviation history: the disappearance of Amelia Earhart after she took off from Lae, New Guinea, in a Lockheed 10-E Electra on July 2, 1937.

title: N.C.A.A. Inquiry Takes On Growing Role of Booster Groups
description: The N.C.A.A. is investigating the University of Tennessee’s football program for recruiting violations involving a group of outside donors, signaling an escalation of efforts to rein in the growing influence of money flooding into college sports, according to documents and people familiar with the case.

title: On Nantucket, a Legal Maneuver to Protect Historic Homes From Gutting
description: On an island where the average home sale topped $4 million last year, Ginger Andrews’s scallop shanty is a golden ticket.

title: The Patty Melt Is Tired of Hearing About Your Favorite Burger
description: We patty-melt people will always be outnumbered by the hamburger people, and we know it.

title: Oregon Leaders Declare Drug Emergency in Portland
description: Oregon leaders on Tuesday declared a 90-day state of emergency in central Portland as part of a broad effort to tackle the effects of fentanyl on the streets of the state’s largest city.

title: The Ballet Roots of a Broadway Star
description: Chita Rivera grew up to be a Broadway queen, but you can’t leave out that she was a ballet kid. Her training began after a botched jump at her family home in Washington, D.C. Rivera — still Dolores Conchita Figueroa del Rivero at the time — landed on the coffee table. It shattered.

title: Tiny Political Party Shuns Amnesty Measure, in Setback for Spanish Leader
description: The fragile coalition of Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain revealed deep and potentially paralyzing cracks on Tuesday when a tiny, hard-line Catalan separatist party he has allied with rejected a critical amnesty measure as unsatisfactory.

title: Wednesday Briefing: Imran Khan Gets 10 Years
description: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s former prime minister, was sentenced to 10 years in prison yesterday. The verdict is widely seen as part of a military campaign to sideline him and his party, and comes about a week before the country’s first national election since Khan was ousted in April 2022.

title: Red Sorghum Brings Vintage Chinese Glamour to Long Island City
description: The 1930s romanticized movie-set look of China, with fringed hanging lanterns, vermilion accents, wicker and greenery, has come to Long Island City. The elaborate new restaurant from Vincent Lin and his business partner, Mandy Zhang, who also own Blue Willow in Midtown Manhattan and Ye’s Apothecary in Chinatown, and their executive chef, Bruce Li, showcase Sichuan and Hunan cooking here. The menu is peppered with Sichuan wontons, Xiang Xi fried rice, Chairman’s braised pork, Chongqing braised beef, peppercorn fish stew and a number of Mala dry pot dishes starring ingredients like pork belly, tripe, Spam, potatoes and mushrooms. Traditional Chinese American standbys like kung pao chicken and lo mein are also served. The drinks list is heavy on the baiju, a spirit made from sorghum and often raised in glasses for celebrations; the list of cocktails mixed with the spirit is extensive, devised by Robert Burns, the mixologist for the partners’ three restaurants. The owners selected a Long Island City location for the diversity of the neighborhood.

title: Microsoft Reports 33% Rise in Profit
description: Two weeks ago, Microsoft topped Apple as the most valuable public company. Last week, it surpassed $3 trillion in market valuation. Next week, Satya Nadella will hit his 10th anniversary as the company’s chief executive.

title: States Where the Death Penalty Has Stalled Look to Alabama
description: Days after Alabama became the first state to put an inmate to death using nitrogen gas, officials elsewhere have started considering the new method of execution.

title: When We Do, and Don’t, Need a New Phrase to Describe Reality
description: In my last newsletter, I argued that it is unsuitably awkward for the word “plagiarism” to be applied both to the stealing of others’ ideas and the copying, perhaps accidentally, of boilerplate text without citing its source. To the extent that most would consider the former an egregious transgression and the latter more of a lazy misstep, English would benefit from using a different term for it.

title: Alphabet’s Search Revenue Disappoints in Fourth Quarter
description: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, on Tuesday reported search revenue and a profit margin for its latest quarter that fell short of Wall Street’s expectations, in a sign that growth in its flagship business and recent layoffs, intended to cut costs, were not enough to offset its growing investment in artificial intelligence.

title: French Lawmakers Vote to Enshrine Abortion Rights in Constitution
description: French lawmakers on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a bill to enshrine abortion rights in France’s Constitution, the first step in a complex legislative process that began in direct response to the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: A Tote Bag for $120?
description: Picture a tote bag. A really big tote bag, cut extra wide to fit your entire farmer’s market haul, with wide straps to evenly distribute weight while you lug your satsuma mandarins and eggs and the kale you’ll forget about and leave to rot in the bottom drawer of your refrigerator. It’s 100 percent cotton, made in the United States and comes in a ballet pink or a lovely faded olive color.

title: Elon Musk’s Tesla Pay Package Is Voided by Judge
description: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, suffered a stunning rebuke Tuesday when a Delaware judge voided the pay package that helped make him a billionaire many times over and the world’s wealthiest human being.

title: Chita Rivera: A Life in Photos
description: The dancer Chita Rivera, who “dazzled audiences for nearly seven decades as a Puerto Rican lodestar of the American musical theater,” has died at 91. Her influence can be seen in many Broadway productions over the years, including “West Side Story” (1957), “Bye Bye Birdie” (1960), “Chicago” (1975) and “Kiss of the Spider Woman” (1993).

title: Prosecutor on Trump Georgia Case Avoids Testifying in Divorce Proceeding
description: The special prosecutor leading the election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump will not have to testify this week about an alleged romantic relationship with his boss, Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, after reaching a temporary agreement in his divorce case on Tuesday.

title: Republicans Push to Impeach Biden’s Homeland Security Chief
description: The Republican-led House panel on homeland security is set to advance articles of impeachment today, seeking to oust Alejandro Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, for his handling of immigration at the southern U.S. border.

title: Letha Dawson Scanzoni, Pioneer of Evangelical Feminism, Dies at 88
description: Letha Dawson Scanzoni, an evangelical author who argued, gently but persuasively, that the Bible considered women equal to men, inspiring a wave of Christian feminism and, perhaps inevitably, a backlash against it, died on Jan. 9 in Charlotte, N.C. She was 88.

title: Elmo Asked an Innocuous Question
description: On Monday the X account for Elmo, the fuzzy red monster from “Sesame Street,” posed a softball question to its 457,000 followers: “Elmo is just checking in! How is everybody doing?”

title: Israel Raids West Bank Hospital as Clashes Erupt With Hamas in Northern Gaza
description: One of the Israeli soldiers wore medical scrubs, another a white coat and surgical mask. Their team swept into the West Bank hospital brandishing rifles, took up positions by the waiting-room chairs, then entered a patient’s room and killed a Hamas commander.

title: Memphis Releases New Footage From Night of Tyre Nichols’s Fatal Beating
description: The city of Memphis released on Tuesday hours of audio, surveillance and police body-camera footage that offered a fuller picture of the night police officers fatally beat Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Black FedEx worker, during a traffic stop last January.

title: Brooklyn Jewish Newspaper’s Ex-Top Editor Pleads Guilty to Jan. 6 Charge
description: A onetime top editor of an Orthodox Jewish newspaper in Brooklyn pleaded guilty on Tuesday to obstructing police officers’ efforts to hold off the mob that stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

title: Biden Says U.S. Response to Deadly Drone Strike in Jordan Has Been Decided
description: President Biden said on Tuesday that he had decided on a U.S. response to the drone attack on a remote outpost in Jordan on Sunday that killed three American soldiers and injured more than 40 others, leaving unstated what that decision was.

title: Pieces of Jackie Robinson Statue Are Found Burning in Kansas Park
description: Parts of a life-size bronze statue that celebrated the legacy of the legendary baseball player and civil rights figure Jackie Robinson were found dismantled and burned early Tuesday after it had been stolen from a Kansas park last week, the authorities said.

title: Ohio Man Who Threw Molotov Cocktails at a Church Gets 18 Years in Prison
description: An Ohio man who prosecutors said had tried to burn down a church in anger by throwing Molotov cocktails at it last year because it planned to host two drag shows was sentenced on Monday to 18 years in prison, federal authorities said.

title: This Ancient Fish Gave the Whole Ocean the Stiff Lower Lip
description: Some 375 million years ago, armored fishes ruled a watery world. Known as placoderms, these primitive jawed vertebrates came in all shapes and sizes, from small bottom-dwellers to giant filter-feeders. Some, like the wrecking-ball-shaped Dunkleosteus, were among the ocean’s earliest apex predators.

title: Parrots Use Their Beaks to Swing Like Monkeys
description: Rosy-faced lovebirds are charismatic, petite parrots. They also aren’t afraid to use their heads — literally — to get around an awkward situation.

title: Major Layoffs at Fair Fight, Voting Rights Group Founded by Stacey Abrams
description: Fair Fight, the liberal voting rights group founded by Stacey Abrams, is laying off most of its staff and scaling back its efforts in response to mounting debts incurred by court battles.

title: Track the Latest Atmospheric Rivers to Hit California and the Pacific Northwest
description: Use these maps to follow the storm’s forecast and impact.

title: What Is Going on at Machu Picchu?
description: Hundreds of tourists were stranded near Machu Picchu, Peru’s most-visited site, over the weekend after demonstrators blocked railway and bus routes to the site and shut down local shops and restaurants in Aguas Calientes, the gateway to Machu Picchu, in the country’s Cuzco region. Some visitors posted videos on social media pleading for help. The police evacuated about 700 tourists on Saturday. Many left without seeing the site.

title: Frozen U.S. Spending for U.N. in Gaza Is Minimal, State Dept. Says
description: The State Department downplayed the significance on Tuesday of its decision to pause funding for the main U.N. aid agency in Gaza, explaining that it had already provided virtually all the money allocated by Congress for that purpose and that the Biden administration hoped the matter could be resolved quickly.

title: Adams vs. Adams: New York’s Top Democrats Clash on City’s Path
description: As Mayor Eric Adams battles low poll ratings, a federal investigation and potential challengers to his re-election in New York City, a Democratic ally has emerged as an unexpected adversary: Adrienne Adams, the City Council speaker.

title: Jean Carnahan, 90, First Woman to Represent Missouri in U.S. Senate, Dies
description: Jean Carnahan, who in 2001 became the first woman to represent Missouri in the U.S. Senate after being appointed to fill her husband’s seat following his posthumous election, died on Tuesday in St. Louis County, Mo. She was 90.

title: Taking Off
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Corrections: Jan. 31, 2024
description: An article on Sunday about a lack of support for Nikki Haley in her home state of South Carolina misstated when Ms. Haley resigned as governor of South Carolina to serve in Donald J. Trump’s administration. It was seven years ago, not eight.

title: Why Tourists Have Been Stranded Near Machu Picchu
description: Demonstrators protesting a new ticketing system blocked access to Peru’s most-visited site and threw rocks at police officers, who fired tear gas into the crowd.

title: Corrections: Jan. 30, 2024
description: An article on Saturday about a United Nations investigation of claims that employees participated in the Oct. 7 attack misstated the number of people working for UNRWA. The agency has 13,000 employees in Gaza alone, not across the world.

title: Melinda Wilson, 77,Who Helped Brian Wilson Through Mental Illness, Dies
description: Melinda Wilson, who rescued her future husband, the Beach Boys co-founder Brian Wilson, from psychological ruin when they were dating in the 1980s, died on Tuesday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 77.

title: Quote of the Day: Monkey Is Living ‘His Best Life’ on the Run in the Scottish Highlands
description: “You would think we were chasing an international fugitive instead of an innocent monkey.”

title: China’s Censorship Dragnet Targets Critics of the Economy
description: China’s top intelligence agency issued an ominous warning last month about an emerging threat to the country’s national security: Chinese people who criticize the economy.

title: The Farmers’ Protests Have Become a Wildfire. He Was the Spark.
description: Jérôme Bayle had spent seven nights on a major French highway, leading a group of aggrieved farmers in protest, when the prime minister arrived, dressed in his Parisian blue suit and tie, to thank them for “making France proud” and announced he would meet their demands.

title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Israeli soldiers raided the Ibn Sina Specialized Hospital in the northern West Bank city of Jenin, killing a Hamas commander. The raid took place as Israel confirmed that it had begun pumping seawater into the vast Hamas tunnel network beneath Gaza to flush out militants and had renewed fighting in northern Gaza.

title: Germany Has Finally Woken Up
description: The ground was icy as my partner, my son and I made our way to the center of Berlin two Sundays ago. Still, as we joined about 100,000 others who had gathered there to protest right-wing extremism, it felt cozy — both in a literal and in a metaphorical sense. The mass of human bodies created a microclimate that made it bearable to be outside in the frosty Berlin dark for a couple of hours. And it was also warming to see this many people turn out to defend our democracy.

title: Word of the Day: auteur
description: The word auteur has appeared in 71 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 2 in “Beyoncé the Auteur Takes Center Stage in ‘Renaissance’” by Salamishah Tillet:

title: Jimmy Kimmel Breaks Down MAGA’s Super Bowl Conspiracy Theories
